head.title: Police in Idaho Searching For a Long Island Woman

hedline.hl1: Police in Idaho Searching For a Long Island Woman

abstract.p: Lynn Henneman, United Airlines flight attendant from Long Island, disappears in Boise, Idaho, where she was on one-night layover; her purse was found near where, police suspect, she may have been out walking; reward is being offered by family and United for information leading to arrest and conviction; photo (M)

block.p: Federal investigators and the police in Boise, Idaho, are searching for a newly married flight attendant from Long Island who never showed up for a flight on Monday morning. They believe she disappeared on Sunday after taking a walk from her hotel in Boise, where she was on a one-night layover.
The woman, Lynn Henneman, 38, of Sag Harbor, has been a United Airlines flight attendant for three years, based at Kennedy International Airport, an airline spokesman said.

Federal investigators and the police in Boise, Idaho, are searching for a newly married flight attendant from Long Island who never showed up for a flight on Monday morning. They believe she disappeared on Sunday after taking a walk from her hotel in Boise, where she was on a one-night layover.
The woman, Lynn Henneman, 38, of Sag Harbor, has been a United Airlines flight attendant for three years, based at Kennedy International Airport, an airline spokesman said.

Ms. Henneman was staying at the Doubletree Hotel Riverside in Garden City, a community within Boise, and went for a walk on the Boise River Greenbelt, the police said. Using credit card records, the police learned that she shopped at a local art museum, had dinner nearby and may have visited a comedy club.
Lt. Jim Tibbs, a spokesman for the Boise police, said yesterday that 20 officers were working on the investigation and that search dogs had been called out.
''We don't know if it was a robbery, we don't know if it was foul play, we don't know if it was sexual, we don't know if it was a kidnapping, we don't know if it was a straight homicide,'' he said.
''We don't know what the motive is at this point, although it's not looking good. Our hopes are dimming.''
A reward of $20,000 -- half provided by the family and half by United Airlines -- is being offered for information leading to an arrest and conviction in Ms. Henneman's disappearance, he said.
Her purse was found near a school, and some of her possessions were found in her hotel room, Lieutenant Tibbs said.
''As far as anything new, they don't have anything since they found her purse,'' Mark Pettet of Idaho Falls, who is married to Ms. Henneman's sister, said of the police.
He said yesterday that the police had been talking to a few transients in the area and that some of them thought they might have talked to her.
''They've kind of chased all the avenues they can. They're not sure where to turn next.''

When a person disappears under mysterious circumstances and kidnapping is a possibility, the Federal Bureau of Investigation becomes involved after 24 hours, because the person may have been taken across state lines.

''We know she went to the art museum and dinner, and that's kind of the end of the trail,'' said Bill Matthews, a special agent with the bureau who is based in Salt Lake City. He said he did not believe Ms. Henneman had any enemies.
Mr. Pettet said the purse was the only evidence suggesting there was any foul play involved in his sister-in-law's disappearance.
''Everything else is totally normal -- her actions, her movements, what she ate, where she ate, her demeanor with the flight crew beforehand,'' he said.
He described Ms. Henneman as a bit of a loner. ''She liked doing things on her own, she knew what she wanted, she made sure she got it,'' he said. ''She was not very much of a socializer.''
He said he did not think she did much with her flight crew outside work. ''She liked to find unique restaurants, she liked to find different food,'' he said. ''She did a lot of that on her own.''

After growing up in a small town -- Livingston, Mont. -- Ms. Henneman spent a lot of time in San Francisco and lived in Manhattan for a while. ''She just really enjoyed going out and seeing the city life and wandering around on her own,'' Mr. Pettet said.

He said the wait for news was weighing heavily on family members. They include Ms. Henneman's parents, who live in Bozeman, Mont.; her sister, who lives in Idaho Falls; her former husband; and her new husband of three weeks, Walter Us.

''I know her husband is going to refuse to leave until something shows up,'' Mr. Pettet said. It is not likely, he said, that she would have disappeared to start a new life. ''That would be totally out of character,'' Mr. Pettet said. ''She always wanted to be a flight attendant, and she was finally there doing it. She had never even been late for a flight.''
In Sag Harbor, a neighbor said she did not see Ms. Henneman or her husband much. ''They were quiet people who kept to themselves,'' said the neighbor, Viola Curley. ''She was busy flying.''
